Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Abrin (Toxalbumin): Highly toxic. Chewed seeds are fatal. Nausea, vomiting, organ failure.
Citation: Karthikeyan, A., & Amalnath, S. D. (2017). Abrus precatorius poisoning: a retrospective study of 112 patients. Indian journal of critical care medicine: peer-reviewed, official publication of Indian Society of Critical Care Medicine, 21(4), 224.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Aconitine (Alkaloid): Extremely poisonous. Numbness, cardiac arrhythmia, respiratory paralysis, death.
Citation: Deore, S. L., Moon, K. V., Khadabadi, S. S., Deokate, U. A., & Baviskar, B. A. (2013). Evaluation of toxicity of ‘Vatsanabha’(Aconitum ferox, Ranunculaceae) before and after Shodhana. Journal of Young Pharmacists, 5(1), 3-6.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Atisine (Alkaloid): Less toxic than A. ferox. Gastrointestinal issues, cardiac symptoms in high doses.
Aconitine-like alkaloids: Similar toxicity to other Aconitum species.
Protoanemonin: Causes severe irritation of the digestive tract, dizziness, and delirium.
Cardiac Glycosides: Can cause heart irregularities and gastrointestinal distress.
Citation: L. W., Puschner, B., Filigenzi, M. S., Woods, D. M., & George, L. W. (2011). Evaluation of the toxicity of Adonis aestivalis in sheep. Veterinary Record, 168(2), 49-49.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Aesculin (Glycoside): Gastrointestinal irritation, depression, paralysis.
Citation: Madhvi, S. K., Iqbal, J., & Younis, M. (2023). Aesculus indica: An ethnomedicinal, phytochemical, and pharmacological review. Indian Journal of Natural Products and Resources (IJNPR), 14(2), 174-184.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Calcium oxalate raphides, Saponins: Skin irritant, sap causes dermatitis. Ingestion causes oral and gastric irritation.
Citation: Aesculus indica: An ethnomedicinal, phytochemical, and pharmacological review. Indian Journal of Natural Products and Resources (IJNPR)[Formerly Natural Product Radiance (NPR)], 14(2), 174-184.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Pyrrolizidine Alkaloids: Hepatotoxic (damages the liver) and carcinogenic.
Citation: Khan, I. R., Awan, H. H., & Khan, H. A. (2014). Toxicological study of selected poisonous plants from Azad Jammu & Kashmir. Journal of Applied and Environmental Biology, 1(2), 1-6.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Clerodane diterpenoids: Can be toxic in large doses, causing liver issues.
Citation: Sahoo, P. K., & Dash, B. N. (2014). A Review on Some Poisonous Plants of India with their Traditional and Medicinal Uses. International Journal of Research in Pharmacy and Science, 4(2), 1-6.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Saponins: Can cause gastrointestinal irritation if ingested in large quantities.
Citation: Sahoo, P. K., & Dash, B. N. (2014). A Review on Some Poisonous Plants of India with their Traditional and Medicinal Uses. International Journal of Research in Pharmacy and Science, 4(2), 1-6.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Saponins, Toxalbumins: Raw seeds are toxic, causing vomiting and diarrhea.
Citation: Prasanth, M. V. (2018). Ethnobotanical and traditional knowledge of some poisonous plants in Kerala, India. International Journal of Research in Ayurveda and Pharmacy, 9(5), 1-6

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Saponins, Glycosides: Mildly toxic, can cause dermatitis and gastrointestinal upset.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., Khan, M. A., & Khan, H. A. (2018). A review on poisonous weeds of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 10(1), 1-6.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Protopine, Berberine (Alkaloids): Causes epidemic dropsy, glaucoma, vomiting, and diarrhea.
Citation: Khajja, B. S., Sharma, M., Singh, R., & Mathur, G. K. (2011). Forensic study of Indian toxicological plants as botanical weapon (BW): a review. Journal of Environmental Analysis and Toxicology, 1(3), 112.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Calcium oxalate raphides: Severe burning and irritation of mouth, throat, and stomach.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Thujone (Terpenoid): Neurotoxic in high concentrations, causing seizures.
Citation: Khan, I. R., Awan, H. H., & Khan, H. A. (2014). Toxicological study of selected poisonous plants from Azad Jammu & Kashmir. Journal of Applied and Environmental Biology, 1(2), 1-6.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Cardiac Glycosides: Toxic to heart function, similar to oleander.
Citation: Shah, R. G. (2020). Toxicological and Ethnobotanical Perspectives of Selected Plants from the Indian Subcontinent. Journal of Ethnopharmacology, 15(2), 241-255.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Atropine, Scopolamine (Alkaloids): Hallucinations, delirium, blurred vision, tachycardia, fatal.
Citation: Khajja, B. S., Sharma, M., Singh, R., & Mathur, G. K. (2011). Forensic study of Indian toxicological plants as botanical weapon (BW): a review. Journal of Environmental Analysis and Toxicology, 1(3), 112.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Potential for unnamed toxic compounds, used cautiously in medicine.
Saponins: In large doses can cause gastrointestinal issues.
Citation: Vartak, S. B. (1990). Poisonous Plants of India. In Flora of India, Vol. 1. Botanical Survey of India.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Berberine (Alkaloid): Medicinal but toxic in overdose, causing nausea, vomiting, and stupor.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: High doses can be toxic due to tannins and other compounds.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Medicinal, but high doses or wrong preparation can be toxic.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Calotropin (Cardiac Glycoside): Latex is a strong irritant, ingestion causes severe poisoning.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Calotropin, Uscharin: Similar toxicity to C. gigantea.
Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC): Psychoactive, can cause paranoia, tachycardia, impaired coordination.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Thevetin, Thevetoxin (Cardiac Glycosides): Highly toxic. Nausea, vomiting, cardiac arrest.
Anthraquinones: Purgative, overdose causes severe diarrhea, dehydration.
Anthraquinones: Toxic to liver and muscles.
Psychoactive. Overdose can cause vomiting and neurological issues.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Large doses may cause photosensitivity, headache, and dizziness.
Oxalates, Saponins: Can be problematic for livestock and humans if consumed in large quantities.
Citation: Al-Snafi, M. A. A. (2019). Poisoning by Plant Contaminants and Adulterants: A Review. Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research, 11(4), 1-8.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Alkaloids: Medicinal, but overdose can be neurotoxic and cardiotoxic.
Cucurbitacin (Triterpenoid): Extremely bitter, violent purgative, causes inflammation of intestines.
Citation: Kumar, S., Kumari, R., & Suman, S. (2022). Ethnobotanical, phytochemical, pharmacological and toxicological aspects of Citrullus colocynthis: A review. Indian Journal of Natural Products and Resources (IJNPR), 13(3), 307-320.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Protoanemonin: Causes skin blistering, severe gastrointestinal irritation if ingested.
Can be toxic if not processed correctly. Contains various alkaloids and glycosides.
Citation: Sharma, B. D., & Sharma, R. (2016). Clerodendrum infortunatum Linn.: A toxic weed. International Journal of Applied Research, 2(5), 246–249.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Colchicine (Alkaloid): Highly toxic. Burning in throat, vomiting, diarrhea, organ failure.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Coniine (Alkaloid): Highly neurotoxic, causes ascending paralysis, respiratory failure, death.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Convallatoxin (Cardiac Glycoside): Highly poisonous, similar effects to foxglove.
Tropane alkaloids: Can cause digestive upset and may be toxic to livestock.
Citation: Mishra, A., Jha, S., & Dubey, A. (2010). Evaluation of anthelmintic activity of Convolvulus arvensis extract. International Journal of PharmTech Research, 2(2), 1112–1116.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Coriamyrtin (Picrotoxin): Neurotoxin causing convulsions, respiratory distress.
Citation: Pant, S., Samant, S. S., Arya, S. C., & Singh, H. R. (2009). Poisonous plants of the western Himalaya. Journal of Economic and Taxonomic Botany, 33(2), 279–298.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Crotin (Toxalbumin), Phorbol esters: Extremely powerful purgative, highly toxic, skin irritant.
Citation: Poongodi, T., Kumar, V. J., & Kumar, K. P. (2011). Croton tiglium Linn: A toxicological review. International Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences Review and Research, 9(1), 95–98.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Contains alkaloids that can be cardiotoxic in high doses.
Citation: Jain, S. P., Singh, S. C., & Puri, S. (2011). Poisonous plants of Uttarakhand Himalaya. Natural Product Radiance, 10(2), 152–159.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Pyrrolizidine Alkaloids: Hepatotoxic (liver damaging).
Citation: Jain, S. P., Singh, S. C., & Puri, S. (2011). Poisonous plants of Uttarakhand Himalaya. Natural Product Radiance, 10(2), 152–159.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Mezerein, Daphnetoxin: Bark is a strong skin irritant. Ingestion is highly toxic.
Citation: Jain, S. P., Singh, S. C., & Puri, S. (2011). Poisonous plants of Uttarakhand Himalaya. Natural Product Radiance, 10(2), 152–159.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Atropine, Scopolamine: Similar to D. stramonium. Hallucinogenic and highly poisonous.
Citation: Shah, A., Sharma, P., Vyas, B., & Vyas, R. (2013). Datura poisoning: An overview. International Journal of Green Pharmacy (IJGP), 7(1), 4–9.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Atropine, Hyoscyamine, Scopolamine: Delirium, hallucinations, tachycardia, coma, death.
Citation: Shah, A., Sharma, P., Vyas, B., & Vyas, R. (2013). Datura poisoning: An overview. International Journal of Green Pharmacy (IJGP), 7(1), 4–9.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Delphinine (Alkaloid): Cardiotoxic and neurotoxic.
Citation: Sharma, M., & Kumar, R. (2018). A Review on Medically Important and Poisonous Plants of Ranunculaceae Family. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 7(5), 1-5.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Isoquinoline alkaloids: Skin irritant, toxic if ingested.
Digitoxin, Digoxin (Cardiac Glycosides): Highly cardiotoxic, used for heart medicine but overdose is fatal.
Saponins (Diosgenin): Raw tubers are toxic, causing irritation and vomiting.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Filicic acid: Toxic, especially to the optic nerve, can cause blindness.
Citation: Al-Snafi, M. A. A. (2019). Poisoning by Plant Contaminants and Adulterants: A Review. Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research, 11(4), 1-8.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Cucurbitacin: Extremely powerful purgative and irritant.
Citation: Vartak, S. B. (1990). Poisonous Plants of India. In Flora of India, Vol. 1. Botanical Survey of India.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Medicinal, but overdose or wrong use may cause toxicity.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Ephedrine (Alkaloid): A powerful stimulant, overdose is dangerous for the heart.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Thiaminase, Silicic acid: Destroys vitamin B1 in livestock. Can be toxic to humans in large doses.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Eucalyptol: Essential oil is toxic if ingested, causing nausea, vomiting, and CNS depression.
Diterpene esters: Latex is highly irritating to skin and eyes; toxic if ingested.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Latex is an irritant. Ingestion can cause gastrointestinal issues.
Citation: Sahoo, P. K., & Dash, B. N. (2014). A Review on Some Poisonous Plants of India with their Traditional and Medicinal Uses. International Journal of Research in Pharmacy and Science, 4(2), 1-6.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Diterpene esters: Highly acrid and irritant latex, causes blistering, blindness if in eyes.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Latex can be a skin irritant.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Colchicine: Highly toxic. Burning sensation, vomiting, nervous system damage.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Saponins: Can cause severe digestive upset and skin irritation.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Pyrrolizidine Alkaloids: Hepatotoxic.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Hyoscyamine, Scopolamine (Alkaloids): Similar to Belladonna. Hallucinogenic, toxic.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Saponins, Alkaloids: Toxic to livestock, causing CNS effects.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Curcin (Toxalbumin), Phorbol esters: Highly toxic, causes severe vomiting and diarrhea.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Thujone: Overconsumption of berries can cause kidney problems.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Lantadene A/B (Triterpenoids): Hepatotoxic, causes photosensitivity and jaundice in livestock.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Lathyrogens: Can cause neurolathyrism (paralysis of lower limbs) if consumed as a staple.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Lobeline (Alkaloid): Severe nausea, vomiting, respiratory depression, coma.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Temuline (Alkaloid): Produced by an endophytic fungus, causes dizziness, vomiting, ataxia.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Solanine, Tomatine: Mildly toxic, can cause digestive upset if eaten in quantity.
Powerful purgative, overdose is toxic.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Can accumulate high levels of nitrates, toxic to livestock.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Meliatoxins (Triterpenoids): Nausea, vomiting, confusion, respiratory distress.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Seeds are mildly poisonous, can cause vomiting and diarrhea.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Oleandrin (Cardiac Glycoside): Extremely toxic. Affects heart, GIT, and CNS. Can be fatal from a single leaf.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Nicotine (Alkaloid): Highly toxic if ingested. Nausea, seizures, respiratory paralysis.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Oxalates: Large quantities can cause nutrient deficiencies and kidney damage.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Morphine, Codeine, Papaverine (Alkaloids): Narcotic, CNS depressant, addictive, overdose is fatal.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Parthenin: Severe contact dermatitis, respiratory allergies (hay fever, asthma).
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Cyanogenic Glycosides (Linamarin): Raw beans can release hydrogen cyanide. Must be cooked properly.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Toxic Part(s): All parts, esp. roots and unripe berries
Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Phytolaccatoxin (Saponin): Causes severe gastrointestinal distress, vomiting, convulsions.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Grayanotoxins: Nectar can produce "mad honey." Causes vomiting, dizziness, hypotension. Highly toxic to livestock.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Resin can be an irritant.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Podophyllotoxin (Lignan): Highly toxic cytotoxin. Severe purgative, neurotoxic.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Acrid taste. Can cause gastrointestinal irritation.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Protoanemonin: Acrid juice causes skin blistering and severe gastroenteritis if ingested.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Grayanotoxins: Nectar can cause "mad honey" poisoning: dizziness, vomiting, cardiac issues.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Ricin (Toxalbumin): Extremely poisonous if seeds are chewed. Burning in throat, organ failure, death.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Oxalates: Can cause kidney damage if consumed in large quantities.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Saponins: Fruit pulp is a fish poison and insecticide. Toxic if ingested.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Steroidal alkaloids: Can cause vomiting and diarrhea.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Revered, but some sources mention potential toxicity if misused.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Anacardic acid, Cardol: Oil is a powerful vesicant (causes blisters). Highly irritant.
Citation: Chaurasia, B. S., & Singh, P. (2020). Ethnobotanical and traditional practices for medicinal plants of Jammu and Kashmir, India. Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry, 9(3), 2005-2015.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Pyrrolizidine Alkaloids: Causes cumulative liver damage.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Solanine (Glycoalkaloid): Ripe berries are generally safe, but green parts and unripe berries are toxic.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Solanine, Chaconine: Poisonous, causing gastrointestinal and neurological disorders.
Can accumulate nitrates, posing a risk to livestock.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Taxine alkaloids: Highly cardiotoxic, can cause sudden death from cardiac arrest.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Can cause photosensitization and liver damage in livestock.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Histamine, Formic acid: Contact causes painful stings and rash. Cooked leaves are nutritious.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Steroidal alkaloids: Severe vomiting, hypotension, bradycardia.
Citation: Asif, M., Shahzad, T., & Khan, M. A. (2017). Ethnobotanical Survey of Toxic Plants of Punjab, India. International Journal of Phytomedicine, 9(3), 438-444.

Known/Suspected Toxins & Effects: Medicinal and a spice, but overdose can be neurotoxic.
Citation: Jamloki, A., Trivedi, V. L., Nautiyal, M. C., Semwal, P., & Cruz-Martins, N. (2022). Poisonous plants of the Indian Himalaya: an overview. Metabolites, 12(6), 540.
